query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Come l’augello, intra l’amate fronde, 2 posato al nido de’ suoi dolci nati 3 la notte che le cose ci nasconde,
4 che, per veder li aspetti disïati 5 e per trovar lo cibo onde li pasca, 6 in che gravi labor li sono aggrati,
7 previene il tempo in su aperta frasca, 8 e con ardente affetto il sole aspetta, 9 fiso guardando pur che l’alba nasca;
10 così la donna mïa stava eretta 11 e attenta, rivolta inver’ la plaga 12 sotto la quale il sol mostra men fretta:
13 sì che, veggendola io sospesa e vaga, 14 fecimi qual è quei che disïando 15 altro vorria, e sperando s’appaga.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Like the bird, among the beloved leaves, 2 perched at the nest of its sweet offspring, 3 the night that hides things from us,
4 that, to see the desired faces 5 and to find the food with which to feed them, 6 in which difficult labors are pleasing to it,
7 anticipates the time on the open branch, 8 and with ardent affection awaits the sun, 9 intently watching for the dawn to break;
10 so my lady stood erect 11 and attentive, turned towards the region 12 under which the sun shows less haste:
13 so that, seeing her suspended and eager, 14 I became like one who, desiring 15 something else, is satisfied with hoping.
**Old English:**
1 Swa ðæt fugel, betwux ðam leofan leafum, 2 geseten æt neste his swetan bearn, 3 ða niht ðe ðing us behlydeð,
4 ðæt, for ðam ðe hit ða gewilnedan wlite 5 and ða mete ðe hit ða fedan sceal, 6 on ðam ðe hefige geswinc him sind geðafian,
7 ðone timan forecuman on ðam openan beorge, 8 and mid hatre lufan ðone sunnan abid, 9 fæste blicende ðæt ðeos niht gewite;
10 swa min lafdi stod uppriht 11 and geornful, gewend to ðære healfe 12 ðær ðe sunne læsran stede hæfð:
13 swa ðæt, ða ic ða geseah ða geswenctan and ða geornan, 14 ic wearð swa se ðe wilniende 15 elles hwilces, and ðurh ða wilnunge bið geblissad.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Pariemi che ’l suo viso ardesse tutto, 23 e li occhi avea di letizia sì pieni, 24 che passarmen convien sanza costrutto.
query.result:
**English:**
22 It seemed to me that his face was all aflame, 23 and his eyes were so full of joy, 24 that I must pass on without understanding.
**Old English:**
22 Þuhte me ðæt his neb eal geblæste, 23 and his eagan wæron swa fulle ðære blisse, 24 ðæt me gebyrede ðæt ic forð gewende butan andsware.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Quale ne’ plenilunïi sereni 26 Trivïa ride tra le ninfe etterne 27 che dipingon lo ciel per tutti i seni,
28 vid’ i’ sopra migliaia di lucerne 29 un sol che tutte quante l’accendea, 30 come fa ’l nostro le viste superne;
31 e per la viva luce trasparea 32 la lucente sustanza tanto chiara 33 nel viso mio, che non la sostenea.
query.result:
**English:**
25 As in the full moons, serene, 26 Trivia rides among the eternal nymphs 27 who paint the sky in all its parts,
28 I saw above thousands of lights 29 a sun that lit them all, 30 as ours does the things above;
31 and through the living light shone 32 the shining substance so bright 33 in my face that I could not bear it.
**Old English:**
25 Swa on ðam beorhtan monan 26 Triuia ritt betwux ðam ecum nihtum 27 ðe ðone heofon hiowiað ofer ealle gesceaft,
28 ic ðær geseah ofer ðusendo leohta 29 an sunne ðe ealle ða oðre onlihte, 30 swa ure sunne ða uferran tunglu;
31 and ðurh ða lybban leoht scineð 32 ða beorhtan gesceaft swa fægere 33 on minre ansyne ðæt ic ða ne mihte geseon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Oh Bëatrice, dolce guida e cara! 35 Ella mi disse: «Quel che ti sobranza 36 è virtù da cui nulla si ripara.
query.result:
**English:**
34 O Beatrice, sweet and dear guide! 35 She said to me: "That which overcomes you 36 is a power from which nothing can protect itself.
**Old English:**
34 Eala, Beatrice, ðu eart min leofe ðu eart min sweteste larðeo! 35 Heo cwæð to me: "Þæt ðe ofercymeð 36 is miht ðe nanwuht ne mæg bewerian.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Quivi è la sapïenza e la possanza 38 ch’aprì le strade tra ’l cielo e la terra, 39 onde fu già sì lunga disïanza».
query.result:
**English:**
37 Here is the wisdom and the power 38 that opened the roads between heaven and earth, 39 whence there was once such a long estrangement.
**Old English:**
37 Þær is wisdom and miht 38 þe ða wegas betweox heofenum and eorðan geopenode, 39 ðanon wæs ær swa langsum sundor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Come foco di nube si diserra 41 per dilatarsi sì che non vi cape, 42 e fuor di sua natura in giù s’atterra,
43 la mente mia così, tra quelle dape 44 fatta più grande, di sé stessa uscìo, 45 e che si fesse rimembrar non sape.
query.result:
**English:**
40 As fire leaps from a cloud 41 to spread out so that it cannot hold itself, 42 and falls to the ground, contrary to its nature,
43 so my mind, among those foods, 44 grew larger and went beyond itself, 45 and it does not know how it was able to remember.
**Old English:**
40 Swa swa fyr of wolcne bið unlocen 41 to ði ðætte hit mæge ða mare weorðan, 42 and of his gecynde hit ðonne on grund fealleð,
43 min mod swa ða ðurh ða metes weorðan 44 mare ðonne hit ær wæs, and of him selfum ut eode, 45 and hu hit ða gewurde hit ne cann areccan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 «Apri li occhi e riguarda qual son io; 47 tu hai vedute cose, che possente 48 se’ fatto a sostener lo riso mio».
query.result:
**English:**
46 "Open your eyes and see who I am; 47 you have seen things that have made you able 48 to endure my smile."
**Old English:**
46 "Unlúc ðíne eágan and geseoh hwæt ic eom; 47 ðu hafast gesewen ðing ðe ðe gedydon habbað 48 ðæt ðu míne hleahtor geþolian miht."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Io era come quei che si risente 50 di visïone oblita e che s’ingegna 51 indarno di ridurlasi a la mente,
52 quand’ io udi’ questa proferta, degna 53 di tanto grato, che mai non si stingue 54 del libro che ’l preterito rassegna.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I was like one who rouses himself 50 from a forgotten vision and strives 51 in vain to bring it back to mind,
52 when I heard this gracious offer, worthy 53 of such gratitude that it never fades 54 from the book that records the past.
**Old English:**
49 Ic wæs swa swa se ðe of slæpe awæcð 50 of gesyhðe forgietenum, and on mode smeað 51 ymb ðæt ðe he geseah, ac hit næfre ne mæg
52 asecgan swa swa hit wæs, ða ic ða spræce gehyrde, 53 ðe wæs swa wynsum, ðæt heo næfre ne mæg 54 of ðam breoste awendan, ðe ða word geheold.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Se mo sonasser tutte quelle lingue 56 che Polimnïa con le suore fero 57 del latte lor dolcissimo più pingue,
58 per aiutarmi, al millesmo del vero 59 non si verria, cantando il santo riso 60 e quanto il santo aspetto facea mero;
61 e così, figurando il paradiso, 62 convien saltar lo sacrato poema, 63 come chi trova suo cammin riciso.
query.result:
**English:**
55 If all those tongues were mine that Polyhymnia 56 with her sisters made more rich 57 with their sweetest milk,
58 to aid me, not even at the thousandth part of the truth 59 would one arrive, singing of the holy laughter 60 and how much the holy aspect made clear;
61 and so, in picturing paradise, 62 the sacred poem must leap forward, 63 like one who finds his path cut off.
**Old English:**
55 Gif ða tungan ealle wæron mine 56 ðe ðe Polyhymnia mid hyre sweostor gefremedon 57 of heora swetestan meolce þa fættestan,
58 to ðam ðe hi me mihton gefultumian, ne mihte ic ðeah 59 on ðusendne dæl ðæs soðan gecweðan, 60 singende ðone halega hleahtor 61 and hu micel se halega hiw ðone man geworhte;
62 and swa ðisne heofonlican gefean figurum, 63 ðonne mot ðæt halige leoð oferhliðan, 64 swa se ðe fint ðæt his weg is forcorfen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Ma chi pensasse il ponderoso tema 65 e l’omero mortal che se ne carca, 66 nol biasmerebbe se sott’ esso trema:
67 non è pareggio da picciola barca 68 quel che fendendo va l’ardita prora, 69 né da nocchier ch’a sé medesmo parca.
query.result:
**English:**
64 But whoever considers the weighty theme 65 and the mortal shoulders that bear it, 66 would not blame him if he trembles beneath it:
67 a small boat is no match 68 for what the daring prow cleaves through, 69 nor is a helmsman who spares himself.
**Old English:**
64 Ac ðeah ðe hwa ðone hefigan ðonc 65 and ðæs deadlican exl ðe hit bired, 66 ne tælige ðone ðeah ðe he ðær ðurh gewite:
67 nis ðæt gelicnes ðæt ðu lytlan scip 68 ðurh ða wægas feran ondsæcge, 69 ne ðæs scipmannes ðe him sylfum sparað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 «Perché la faccia mia sì t’innamora, 71 che tu non ti rivolgi al bel giardino 72 che sotto i raggi di Cristo s’infiora?
73 Quivi è la rosa in che ’l verbo divino 74 carne si fece; quivi son li gigli 75 al cui odor si prese il buon cammino».
query.result:
**English:**
70 "Why does my face so enamor you, 71 that you do not turn to the beautiful garden 72 that blossoms beneath the rays of Christ?
73 There is the rose in which the divine Word 74 became flesh; there are the lilies 75 whose fragrance led us to take the good path."
**Old English:**
70 "Hwi ðin neb swa ðe on lust bið, 71 ðæt ðu nelt wenan to ðam wlitigum wyrtgearde 72 ðe under Cristes sunnan scinð?
73 Þær is ðæt rose ðær ðæt godcunde word 74 wearð on menniscnesse; þær synd ða lilian 75 ðara stenc us lædde on ðone godan weg."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Così Beatrice; e io, che a’ suoi consigli 77 tutto era pronto, ancora mi rendei 78 a la battaglia de’ debili cigli.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Thus Beatrice; and I, who to her counsels 77 was all prompt, surrendered myself again 78 to the battle of the feeble eyes.
**Old English:**
76 Þus cwæð Beatrijs; and ic, ðe to hire rædum 77 eall gearu wæs, eft me geaf 78 to ðære gewinne ðara wanhaligra eagna.

**English:**
79 Like a ray of sunlight, which purer 80 through broken clouds, a meadow of flowers 81 covered in shadow, my eyes saw;
82 so I saw many throngs of splendors, 83 struck from above by burning rays, 84 without seeing the source of the lightning.
**Old English:**
79 Swa swa sunnan gim, ðe scireð swiðost 80 ðurh ðone wolcna hrægl, ðæt wyrtum blostmum 81 oferhiðað, ða ða hi beorgas wrixlað,
82 swa ic ðær geseah menigo ðara gasta 83 beorhte scinende, ðurh ðæs beorna geðanc, 84 ac ðæs leoman fruman ne mihte ic findan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 O benigna vertù che sì li ’mprenti, 86 sù t’essaltasti, per largirmi loco 87 a li occhi lì che non t’eran possenti.
query.result:
**English:**
85 O benign power that dost so imprint them, 86 thou didst exalt thyself to give me place 87 beside the eyes that were not potent to see thee.
**Old English:**
85 Eala ðu milde miht ðe ðus ða geondwlitast, 86 ðu ðe selfne upahofe, ðæt ðu me stede sealde 87 wið ða eagan ðe ðe ne mihton geseon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Il nome del bel fior ch’io sempre invoco 89 e mane e sera, tutto mi ristrinse 90 l’animo ad avvisar lo maggior foco;
91 e come ambo le luci mi dipinse 92 il quale e il quanto de la viva stella 93 che là sù vince come qua giù vinse,
94 per entro il cielo scese una facella, 95 formata in cerchio a guisa di corona, 96 e cinsela e girossi intorno ad ella.
query.result:
**English:**
88 The name of the fair flower that I always invoke 89 morning and evening, wholly drew 90 my mind to contemplate the greater fire;
91 and as both my eyes were painted 92 by the quality and quantity of the living star 93 that conquers up there as it conquered down here,
94 a torch descended through the sky, 95 formed in a circle like a crown, 96 and encircled and revolved around it.
**Old English:**
88 Se nama ðæs fægran blostman ðe ic symble clipian 89 morgen and æfen, eall me geræhte 90 ðone mod to geþencanne ðone mæran fyr;
91 and swa swa he me gefrætwode begen ða gesyhðe 92 ðæs lyfigendan steorran hu micel and hu mære 93 ðe ðær ufan sigorðeð swa he her niðor dyde,
94 ðurh ðone lyft com liðan an leoht, 95 geworht on hweorfe swa corona, 96 and beclypte ða and ymb ða eode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Qualunque melodia più dolce suona 98 qua giù e più a sé l’anima tira, 99 parrebbe nube che squarciata tona,
100 comparata al sonar di quella lira 101 onde si coronava il bel zaffiro 102 del quale il ciel più chiaro s’inzaffira.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Whatever melody sounds sweetest 98 here below and most draws the soul to itself, 99 would seem a cloud that thunders, torn apart,
100 compared to the sound of that lyre 101 with which the fair sapphire was crowned, 102 with which the clearest heaven is adorned.
**Old English:**
97 Swylce mægð ðe mæst murnende 98 hlude hremende hleðor swinsade, 99 þuhte þæt wolcnu wundorlic hlude
100 wið þæs hearpan sweg ðe he on handa bær, 101 þær he mid wynne wuldres prym 102 on þam heahsetle heofona rices.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Così la circulata melodia 110 si sigillava, e tutti li altri lumi 111 facean sonare il nome di Maria.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Thus the circling melody 110 sealed itself, and all the other lights 111 made the name of Mary resound.
**Old English:**
109 Swa ðæt ymbegangende gyd 110 hit sylfe gesette, and ealle ða odre leoht 111 Marienan naman mærdon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Lo real manto di tutti i volumi 113 del mondo, che più ferve e più s’avviva 114 ne l’alito di Dio e nei costumi,
115 avea sopra di noi l’interna riva 116 tanto distante, che la sua parvenza, 117 là dov’ io era, ancor non appariva:
118 però non ebber li occhi miei potenza 119 di seguitar la coronata fiamma 120 che si levò appresso sua semenza.
query.result:
**English:**
112 The royal mantle of all volumes 113 of the world, which most burns and most quickens 114 in the breath of God and in the ways of men,
115 had above us its inner shore 116 so distant that its appearance, 117 where I was, did not yet appear:
118 therefore my eyes had no power 119 to follow the crowned flame 120 that rose after its seed.
**Old English:**
112 Se cynelica wyrðmynd ealra boca 113 middangeardes, ðe mæst byrnende is and mæst geliffæst 114 on Godes blæst and on manna gewunan,
115 hæfde ofer us ða innweardne brerd 116 swa feor, ðæt his hiw, 117 ðær ic wæs, næs gyt gesyne:
118 forðæm ne mihton mine eagan habban mægen 119 ðæt hi ða gecornadan leg fylgdon 120 ðe aras æfter his sæde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Indi rimaser lì nel mio cospetto, 128 ‘Regina celi’ cantando sì dolce, 129 che mai da me non si partì ’l diletto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Then they remained there before me, 128 singing ‘Regina celi’ so sweetly, 129 that the delight never departed from me.
**Old English:**
127 Þa hi ðær wunedon on ðam wlite, 128 ‘Regina celi’ singende swa swetlice, 129 ðæt næfre fram me ne gewat ðæt gefea.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Oh quanta è l’ubertà che si soffolce 131 in quelle arche ricchissime che fuoro 132 a seminar qua giù buone bobolce!
133 Quivi si vive e gode del tesoro 134 che s’acquistò piangendo ne lo essilio 135 di Babillòn, ove si lasciò l’oro.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Oh, how great is the abundance that is sown 131 in those most rich arks that were 132 to sow good seeds down here!
133 Here one lives and enjoys the treasure 134 that was acquired with weeping in the exile 135 of Babylon, where gold was left behind.
**Old English:**
130 Eala, hu micel is ðæt oferflæd ðe bið gesawen 131 on ðam swipe miclum arce ðe wæron 132 to sawenne her niðer gode sædmenn!
133 Þær man leofað and brucað ðæs goldhordes 134 ðe man begeat wepende on ðam wræcsetle 135 Babilonie, ðær man gold forlet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Quivi trïunfa, sotto l’alto Filio 137 di Dio e di Maria, di sua vittoria, 138 e con l’antico e col novo concilio,
139 colui che tien le chiavi di tal gloria.
query.result:
**English:**
136 There triumphs, beneath the lofty Son 137 of God and Mary, in his victory, 138 and with the old and the new council,
139 he who holds the keys to such glory.
**Old English:**
136 Þær sigorað se under ðæs Hehstan Bearn 137 Godes and Marian, his sigeweorðunge, 138 and mid ðam ealdan and ðam niwan gegaderunge,
139 se ðe ða cægðas hæfð ðæs wuldres.
